p: Being an anionic polymer, PAA can readily incorporate cations, such as Mg 2+ in the starting solution. Here, we use Mg other than Li because Li cannot be detected by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). As shown in Fig. S12A, elemental mapping confirms a relatively uniform Mg distribution, along with C and O, on as-coated CCF. However, if such CCF is next cycled 50 times (at 50 mV s −1) between −1.0 V and 1.0 V in a Mg-free 0.5 M H 2SO 4 electrolyte, then 90% of the Mg content is gone (Figure S12B), presumably replaced by H +. Subsequently, Mg 2+ can be reintroduced to the coating by repeating cyclic voltammetry (CV) for another 50 cycles, this time in 2 M MgSO 4 electrolyte. By now, the Mg content in the coating has increased by a factor of 3 (Fig. S12C), but it is still 75% below the original value (Fig. S12A). Therefore, the majority of metal ions in the as-deposited coating is probably trapped though not structurally bound to the polymer, so they can leave and reenter coating as dictated by the electrolyte composition and electrode's voltage/polarity. This ability to accommodate cations to various extents is natural for a weak acid like PAA, which can readily protonate/deprotonate to maintain charge neutrality.
